messageBody:
I've since discovered the RepeatedTest class within JUnit which seems to
answer my earlier question. Perhaps someone can let me know if the
following code seems OK?

/**
* Runs all tests in ArticleNounTest once, and then runs the
* random test several times.
*/
public static Test suite() {
TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(ArticleNounTest.class);
suite.addTest(new RepeatedTest(new ArticleNounTest("testRandom"), 20));
return suite;
}

Using RepeatedTest replaces the following lines of code:
//for (int i=0; i<20; i++)
// suite.addTest(new ArticleNounTest("testRandom"));
Is there any other advantage to using RepeatedTest instead of the
above "for" loop? Perhaps RepeatedTest reports its findings in a
nicer way than the "for" loop would? The JavaDoc for RepeatedTest
only states that it is "A Decorator that runs a test repeatedly."

As to what I am testing and why use randomness:
I'm testing a little program for learning Italian; the program
randomly generates short phrases in English and then the student
supplies the corresponding Italian... so I want to have the tests
do their random generation of several different phrases.
(I'm not testing how random the behavior is, I just want to
throw a bunch of random possibilities at my code to get the
code to break).

Regards,
--ErikN

Testing random behaviour is very difficult. After all how will you know it
when you see it? If you get exactly the randomness that you were looking
for, wouldn't that mean that there was a problem with your randomness?

On 6/16/05, eriknusanet <erikn@...> wrote:
> Hi, I'm new to JUnit. I'm wondering what is the right way to set up
> some random tests?
>
> Should I just put into my tests a loop runs the test multiple times?
> This seems to imply that the test needs to call setUp() to get some
> fresh objects ("test fixture") each time through the loop, which seems
> somehow wrong (at least I've seen no examples like this). Is there
> some better way to ask for a test to be run N times?
>
> I got turned on to JUnit from the book
> Building Parsers with JavaT by Steven John Metsker
> however it seems that he does not use JUnit for random tests. He has
> a section extolling JUnit, but then a section immediately after about
> random testing that doesn't use JUnit at all.
>
> Perhaps random testing is not considered part of unit testing? If so,
> why?
>
> Thanks for the help.
> --Erik N
